linkTarget.anchoringText: The same problem exists with GCF and in case of downhole sampling with self-contained downhole samplers. The near-wellbore formation pressure quickly drops below the dew point and fluid phase segregation starts in the wellbore. In other words, the period of stable fluid (single phase formation gas) inflow at GCF can’t be achieved as near-wellbore formation pressure quickly drops below the dew point. This is well illustrated by the phase diagram of gas condensate (Fig.1) taken from a fundamental work of Prof. J. McCain [12].

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: p-T phase diagram [12] of gas condensate. When formation pressure (1) drops below the dew point (2)-(3), heavy fractions fall out in the formation resulting in a condensate bank around the producing well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: p-T phase diagram [12] of gas condensate. When formation pressure (1) drops below the dew point (2)-(3), heavy fractions fall out in the formation resulting in a condensate bank around the producing well.

linkTarget.bib:
McCain, 1990
W. D. McCain , The Properties of Petroleum Fluids , Second Edition, Penn Well, 1990.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Another group of problems is associated with changes in thermodynamic conditions in situ and in the production system. Temperature decreasing creates conditions for gas hydrate deposition, mainly in the tubing and surface piping system, which can result in system plugging and emergency production stop. In case of relatively shallow reservoirs in permafrost areas, gas hydrates are usually also accumulated in gas saturated beds above the gas reservoir. Gas hydrate layer destruction is associated with methane explosion funnels revealed on the Yamal, Taimyr and Gydan Peninsulas in recent years (Fig. 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Methane explosion crater in northern Siberia

formatted-caption.caption-text: Methane explosion crater in northern Siberia

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to American companies [5], an average well production rate decrease during the first year of development for most shale gas plays is from 54% to 77%. According to statistical data on Haynesville field (USA), production volumes of 60 wells initially flowed through large size chokes reduced by 83% within the first year. At the same time, production volumes of wells that flowed through smaller chokes (5.5mm) reduced by 38% only. Proper choke sizes, i.e. optimization of producer well operation enables to extend the well production life and increase the total cumulative production by 30% (Fig. 3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Optimal choke sizes improve condensate recover rates (CRR) and hydrocarbon recovery rates in general [5].

formatted-caption.caption-text: Optimal choke sizes improve condensate recover rates (CRR) and hydrocarbon recovery rates in general [5].

linkTarget.bib:
Eresman, 2012
R. Eresman , Encana Presentation at Global LNG Summit , 2012.

linkTarget.anchoringText: A similar method of total flow measurement is also used in surface multiphase flowmeters [8, 9]. The Alpha VS (Venturi-Sonar) multiphase flowmeter is designed to provide two-phase flow rate measurements (gas – liquid) for wet gas flow streams. These are generally flow streams with greater than 90% gas volume fraction (GVF). Full three phase flow measurement can be achieved by adding a Red Eye® MP infrared water cut meter. A typical configuration for an Alpha VSR multiphase meter can be seen in Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Block diagram of Alpha VS/R wet gas surface flowmeter. (1) – Sonar-Venturi module; (2) – Module with Red Eye-MP multiphase water cut meter.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Block diagram of Alpha VS/R wet gas surface flowmeter. (1) – Sonar-Venturi module; (2) – Module with Red Eye-MP multiphase water cut meter.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Flowmeter nominal sizes range from 2 to 10 inches with some overlap in operating envelope (Figure 5). For example, a well producing 7 MMscf/day of gas (200,000 m3/d) and 200 b/d of liquid (30 m3/d) fits within the operating envelope of a 3”, 4” and 6” meter. The blue “low” bars represent the minimum measureable rate and the red “high” bars represent the maximum measureable rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Nomogram for Alpha VS/R size selection depending on expected gas and condensate flow rates. The green arrow shows the operating range of VS/R- 4” model for the line pressure of 20 bar and temperature of 40°C. A well with the gas flow rate of 200,000 m3/day and condensate flow rate of 30 m3/day is in the center of the operating range.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Nomogram for Alpha VS/R size selection depending on expected gas and condensate flow rates. The green arrow shows the operating range of VS/R- 4” model for the line pressure of 20 bar and temperature of 40°C. A well with the gas flow rate of 200,000 m3/day and condensate flow rate of 30 m3/day is in the center of the operating range.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fiber-optic measuring systems have a flexible configuration and may incorporate various sensors (Fig. 6). Optical cable feature three or four cores and reliable protection. Up to 4 sensors (P, T) or up to 8 seismic receivers or a flowmeter and two pressure/temperature gauges, or a system of temperature micro-sensors, or various sensor combinations can be installed on one core. One special (multi-mode) core is designed for continuous temperature profile measurements along the wellbore (DTS).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Flexible configuration of optical monitoring systems on a 3-core optic-fiber cable. Each optic fiber can support a wide range of monitoring sensor combinations for any applications.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Flexible configuration of optical monitoring systems on a 3-core optic-fiber cable. Each optic fiber can support a wide range of monitoring sensor combinations for any applications.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Real time optimization of multi-stage fracturing during shale play development requires measuring of separate fractures (Fig. 7). Unsteady character of the shale play production process results in inappropriate logging data. Continuous real time data updating and analysis is necessary for determining the contribution of separate fractures in the total production. Several sensors (P, T), DST system along the whole wellbore length and a surface flowmeter are installed in the well for this purpose. These data are acquired by Field Office operating intellectual field support system and processed using a special algorithm [20].

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Real time multi-stage fracturing optimization at a shale gas play [20].

formatted-caption.caption-text: Real time multi-stage fracturing optimization at a shale gas play [20].

linkTarget.bib:
Gonzalez and Chokshi, 2012
L. E. Gonzalez , R.N. Chokshi , Weatherford Int’l.- Wellbore Real-Time Monitoring and Analysis for Shale Reservoirs .- SPE 154520-MS, 2012.

linkTarget.anchoringText: New catalytic methods enable removing hydrogen sulfide and mercaptans, including fat ones, from hydrocarbons within 1–2 process stages. The technology of oil and associated gas desulphurization [21] is also conceptually applicable for gas condensate refinement (Fig. 8). This technology is compatible with process solutions for preliminary processing of oil and gas condensate. It should be emphasized that hydrogen sulfide and mercaptans removing from oil and associated gas may be performed within a single process flow diagram.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Basic natural gas and condensate desulphurization diagram

formatted-caption.caption-text: Basic natural gas and condensate desulphurization diagram

linkTarget.anchoringText: The technological process is based on hydrocarbons catalytic conversion during catalytic and thermal treatment with a maximum quantity of high quality light products. The catalytic modules include original hydrodynamic modules for raw materials processing; they enable improving the catalyst service life and process performance. Special cavitation devices provide sonic and hydrodynamic resonance, extending the catalyst service life. The whole unit is housed in two modular containers weighting about 25 tons, and has feed capacity of up to 50 ton of condensate per day (Fig. 9).

The chart of gas condensate processing is shown in Fig. 10. Stabilized condensate (or furnace oil) enters the recovery unit, where it is heated to 80°C. Light fractions (C2-C6) after evaporation proceed directly into the separator, while heavier liquid fractions preliminarily pass through a catalytic unit, where their cracking takes place. The mixture gas-liquid separation is performed in the separator. By means of cooling the liquid is separated into corresponding storage tanks for diesel oil, lubrication oil and gasoline. The gases enter the gas-distributing unit.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Process flow diagram – POL production from stable condensate by catalytic thermal cracking

formatted-caption.caption-text: Process flow diagram – POL production from stable condensate by catalytic thermal cracking

linkTarget.anchoringText: The catalytic process technologies are continuously studied and improved using equipment of the engineering chemical technological center (Fig. 11).

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Equipment for research and development of catalytic processes in the engineering chemical technological center

formatted-caption.caption-text: Equipment for research and development of catalytic processes in the engineering chemical technological center

linkTarget.anchoringText: Infrared gas burners with pressed wire matrix are made of scale-resistant wires. They differ from ceramic matrixes in terms of their shock resistance, mechanical strength and elasticity; they are not susceptible to cracking when get on a heated surface of the cold product (Fig. 12). The structure of pressed wire goods is a braiding of specifically oriented wire spirals, which after gradual cold pressing in special press molds form an open porous system, permeable in all directions; such systems provide necessary mechanical, physical, hydrodynamic and other properties (Fig. 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Experimental prototypes of pressed wire devices: infrared gas furnace

formatted-caption.caption-text: Experimental prototypes of pressed wire devices: infrared gas furnace

linkTarget.anchoringText: Infrared gas burners with pressed wire matrix are made of scale-resistant wires. They differ from ceramic matrixes in terms of their shock resistance, mechanical strength and elasticity; they are not susceptible to cracking when get on a heated surface of the cold product (Fig. 12). The structure of pressed wire goods is a braiding of specifically oriented wire spirals, which after gradual cold pressing in special press molds form an open porous system, permeable in all directions; such systems provide necessary mechanical, physical, hydrodynamic and other properties (Fig. 13).

Besides, the region is rich in asbestos, mica, diamond fields and other nonmetallic mineral resources. Ore formations of rare metal and mica pegmatites are typical of the Archaean granite-gneiss domes (Anabar solid mass, Dzhugdzhur, Biryusinsk block mass, Fig. 14, 15). The major solid masses of mineral resources are concentrated in supracrustal belts (ilmenite-titanium magnetite mineralization), iron ore fields of formations of magnetite calc-silicate hornfels (South-Aldan iron-ore area) and ferruginous quartzite (Chara-Tokkin iron-ore area).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Gas and gas condensate fields of Western Siberia (red and pink) are concentrated in the northern part of the area. Source: Blackbourn Geological Services Ltd. [26].

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas and gas condensate fields of Western Siberia (red and pink) are concentrated in the northern part of the area. Source: Blackbourn Geological Services Ltd. [26].

linkTarget.bib: [26] Blackbourn Geological Services Ltd.: “Western Siberia Hydrocarbon regions”, 2014. http://www.blackbourn.co.uk/

linkTarget.anchoringText: Besides, the region is rich in asbestos, mica, diamond fields and other nonmetallic mineral resources. Ore formations of rare metal and mica pegmatites are typical of the Archaean granite-gneiss domes (Anabar solid mass, Dzhugdzhur, Biryusinsk block mass, Fig. 14, 15). The major solid masses of mineral resources are concentrated in supracrustal belts (ilmenite-titanium magnetite mineralization), iron ore fields of formations of magnetite calc-silicate hornfels (South-Aldan iron-ore area) and ferruginous quartzite (Chara-Tokkin iron-ore area).

Source: Blackbourn Geological Services Ltd. [27].
